15.title: Liability of buyer to make payment
15.content: Where any supplier supplies any goods or renders any services to any buyer, the buyer shall make payment therefor on or before the date agreed upon between him and the supplier in writing or, where there is no agreement in this behalf, before the appointed day. Provided that in no case the period agreed upon between the supplier and the buyer in writing shall exceed forty-five days from the day of acceptance or the day of deemed acceptance.
key_points: Payment must be made on the agreed date
If no agreement, payment due within 15 days of acceptance
Maximum payment period cannot exceed 45 days from acceptance
Acceptance includes deemed acceptance

15a.title: Appointed day (Definition)
15a.content: The 'appointed day' means the day following immediately after the expiry of the period of fifteen days from the day of acceptance or the day of deemed acceptance of any goods or any services by a buyer from a supplier.
key_points: Appointed day = 15 days after acceptance
Applies when no written agreement on payment date

16.title: Date from which and rate at which interest is payable
16.content: Where any buyer fails to make payment of the amount to the supplier, as required under section 15, the buyer shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement between the buyer and the supplier or in any law for the time being in force, be liable to pay compound interest with monthly rests to the supplier on that amount from the appointed day or, as the case may be, from the date immediately following the date agreed upon, at three times of the bank rate notified by the Reserve Bank.
key_points: Interest = 3 times RBI bank rate (currently 6.50% x 3 = 19.50% p.a.)
Compound interest with monthly rests
Interest runs from appointed day or agreed date
Overrides any contrary agreement
Overrides any other law
16.formula: A = P * (1 + r/12)^n where r = 3 * bank_rate, n = months

17.title: Buyer not to be allowed certain claims
17.content: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, the buyer shall not be entitled to claim any amount paid or payable under or in accordance with the provisions of section 16 (interest on delayed payment) as expenditure or deduction or allowance for the purposes of computation of income under the Income-tax Act, 1961.
key_points: Interest paid under Section 16 is NOT tax-deductible
Buyer cannot claim it as business expenditure
This is a penalty provision to discourage delayed payments

18.title: Reference to Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council
18.content: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, any party to a dispute may, with regard to any amount due under section 17, make a reference to the Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council (MSEFC). (2) On receipt of a reference under sub-section (1), the Council shall conduct or get conducted conciliation in the matter. (3) Where the conciliation is not successful within such period as may be prescribed, the Council shall either itself take up the dispute for arbitration or refer it to any institution or centre providing alternate dispute resolution services. (4) The Council shall dispose of the dispute within 90 days from the date of making such a reference.
key_points: Either party can file reference with MSEFC
MSEFC first attempts conciliation
If conciliation fails, proceeds to arbitration
Must dispose within 90 days (extendable to 180 days)
No court fee required for filing

sub_sections.18(1): Either party can make reference to MSEFC for amount due
sub_sections.18(2): MSEFC shall conduct or get conducted conciliation
sub_sections.18(3): If conciliation fails, MSEFC takes up arbitration or refers to ADR centre
sub_sections.18(4): Disposal within 90 days from date of reference

19.title: Application for setting aside decree, award or order
19.content: No application for setting aside any decree, award or other order made either by the Council itself or by any institution or centre referred to in sub-section (3) of section 18 shall be entertained by any court unless the appellant (not being the supplier) has deposited with it seventy-five percent of the amount in terms of the decree, award or order.
key_points: To challenge MSEFC order, buyer must deposit 75% of awarded amount
This provision protects supplier's interest
Only non-supplier (buyer) needs to make deposit
Applies to decrees, awards, and orders

20.title: Establishment of Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Councils
20.content: The State Government shall, by notification, establish one or more Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Councils at such places, exercising such jurisdiction and for such areas, as may be specified in the notification.
key_points: State Governments establish MSEFCs
MSEFCs have territorial jurisdiction
Multiple MSEFCs can exist per state
Established by state notification

21.title: Composition of Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council
21.content: The Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council shall consist of not less than three but not more than five members to be appointed by the State Government.
key_points: 3 to 5 members
Appointed by State Government
Includes Director of Industries (ex-officio)
Includes representatives of banks, MSME associations

22.title: Duties of buyer â€” Filing of statement
22.content: Where a buyer is required to get his annual accounts audited under any law for the time being in force, such buyer shall furnish the following additional information in his annual statement of accounts: (i) the principal amount and the interest due thereon remaining unpaid to any supplier as at the end of each accounting year; (ii) the amount of interest paid by the buyer in terms of section 16; (iii) the amount of the payment made to the supplier beyond the appointed day during each accounting year; (iv) the amount of interest accrued and remaining unpaid at the end of each accounting year; (v) the amount of further interest remaining due and payable even in the succeeding years.
key_points: Buyers must disclose MSME dues in annual accounts
Must report unpaid principal and interest
Must report delayed payments made during the year
Must report accrued interest
Applies to all audited entities

2_definitions.title: Key Definitions under MSMED Act 2006
2_definitions.content: Important definitions for dispute resolution context.

definitions.micro_enterprise: Investment in plant & machinery up to Rs. 1 crore and turnover up to Rs. 5 crore
definitions.small_enterprise: Investment in plant & machinery up to Rs. 10 crore and turnover up to Rs. 50 crore
definitions.medium_enterprise: Investment in plant & machinery up to Rs. 50 crore and turnover up to Rs. 250 crore
definitions.supplier: A micro or small enterprise which has filed a memorandum with the authority
definitions.buyer: Whoever buys any goods or receives any services from a supplier for consideration
definitions.appointed_day: Day following 15 days from acceptance/deemed acceptance of goods/services

odr_process.title: Online Dispute Resolution (ODR) Process for MSME Disputes
odr_process.content: The ODR mechanism provides a 4-phase digital resolution process for MSME delayed payment disputes.

phase_1_dgp.name: Digital Guided Pathway (DGP)
phase_1_dgp.description: AI-driven preliminary assessment where parties understand likely outcomes before formal proceedings

phase_2_unp.name: Unmanned Negotiation Platform (UNP)
phase_2_unp.description: AI-facilitated negotiation where parties exchange offers with AI guidance

phase_3_conciliation.name: Conciliation
phase_3_conciliation.description: Human conciliator-assisted resolution with AI support for documentation

phase_4_arbitration.name: Arbitration
phase_4_arbitration.description: Formal binding arbitration proceedings via MSEFC
